messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 60 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Fast Online Node Labeling for Very Large Graphs

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper studies the online node classification problem under a transductive learning setting. Current methods either invert a graph kernel matrix with 𝒪​(n3)𝒪superscript𝑛3\mathcal{O}(n^{3}) runtime and 𝒪​(n2)𝒪superscript𝑛2\mathcal{O}(n^{2}) space complexity or sample a large volume of random spanning trees, thus are difficult to scale to large graphs. In this work, we propose an improvement based on the online relaxation technique introduced by a series of works (Rakhlin et al., 2012; Rakhlin & Sridharan, 2015, 2017). We first prove an effective regret 𝒪​(n1+γ)𝒪superscript𝑛1𝛾\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{n^{1+\gamma}}) when suitable parameterized graph kernels are chosen, then propose an approximate algorithm FastONL enjoying 𝒪​(k​n1+γ)𝒪𝑘superscript𝑛1𝛾\mathcal{O}(k\sqrt{n^{1+\gamma}}) regret based on this relaxation. The key of FastONL is a generalized local push method that effectively approximates inverse matrix columns and applies to a series of popular kernels. Furthermore, the per-prediction cost is 𝒪​(vol⁡(𝒮)​log⁡1/ϵ)𝒪vol𝒮1italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(\operatorname{vol}\left(\mathcal{S}\right)\log 1/\epsilon) locally dependent on the graph with linear memory cost. Experiments show that our scalable method enjoys a better tradeoff between local and global consistency.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 60 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 60"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The political blogosphere and the 2004 us election: divided they blog",
        "Local graph partitioning using pagerank vectors",
        "Robust pagerank and locally computable spam detection features",
        "Eigenvalues of the laplacian of a graph",
        "Learning on graph with laplacian regularization",
        "Bookmark-coloring algorithm for personalized pagerank computing",
        "Learning from labeled and unlabeled data using graph mincuts",
        "Combining labeled and unlabeled data with co-training",
        "Semi-supervised learning using randomized mincuts",
        "Scaling graph neural networks with approximate pagerank",
        "Fast and optimal prediction on a labeled tree",
        "Random spanning trees and the prediction of weighted graphs",
        "Spectral graph theory, volume 92",
        "The DBpedia ontology",
        "Asymptotic behavior of\\ackslashell_p-based laplacian regularization in semi-supervised learning",
        "Differentially private graph learning via sensitivity-bounded personalized pagerank",
        "Open problem: Running time complexity of accelerated ℓ1subscriptℓ1\\ell_{1}-regularized pagerank",
        "Variational perspective on local graph clustering",
        "p𝑝p-laplacian based graph neural networks",
        "Combining neural networks with personalized pagerank for classification on graphs",
        "Online similarity prediction of networked data from known and unknown graphs",
        "Community structure in social and biological networks",
        "Matrix computations",
        "Online spectral learning on a graph with bandit feedback",
        "Introduction to online convex optimization",
        "Exploiting cluster-structure to predict the labeling of a graph",
        "Predicting the labelling of a graph via minimum p-seminorm interpolation",
        "Prediction on a graph with a perceptron",
        "Online prediction of switching graph labelings with cluster specialists",
        "Online learning over graphs",
        "Online prediction on large diameter graphs",
        "Fast prediction on a tree",
        "Predicting a switching sequence of graph labelings",
        "A gang of adversarial bandits",
        "Open graph benchmark: Datasets for machine learning on graphs",
        "Scaling personalized web search",
        "On the effectiveness of laplacian normalization for graph semi-supervised learning",
        "Graph-based semi-supervised learning and spectral kernel design",
        "Semi-supervised classification with graph convolutional networks",
        "Towards real-time community detection in large networks",
        "Eigenvalues, diameter, and mean distance in graphs",
        "Query-driven active surveying for collective classification",
        "On spectral clustering: Analysis and an algorithm",
        "The PageRank citation ranking: Bringing order to the web",
        "Deepwalk: Online learning of social representations",
        "Hierarchies of relaxations for online prediction problems with evolving constraints",
        "Bistro: An efficient relaxation-based method for contextual bandits",
        "A tutorial on online supervised learning with applications to node classification in social networks",
        "Efficient online multiclass prediction on graphs via surrogate losses",
        "Relax and randomize: From value to algorithms",
        "Collective classification in network data",
        "Online learning and online convex optimization",
        "Worst-case complexity of cyclic coordinate descent: o​(n2)𝑜superscript𝑛2o(n^{2}) gap with randomized version",
        "See the tree through the lines: The shazoo algorithm",
        "Generating random spanning trees more quickly than the cover time",
        "Unifying the global and local approaches: an efficient power iteration with forward push",
        "Graph convolutional neural networks for web-scale recommender systems",
        "Approximate personalized pagerank on dynamic graphs",
        "Learning with local and global consistency",
        "Semi-supervised learning using gaussian fields and harmonic functions"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 60 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Fast Online Node Labeling for Very Large Graphs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
